title: Patkai
text:
The Pat-kai (Pron:pʌtˌkaɪ) or Patkai Bum (<a href="Burmese%20language">Burmese</a>: "Kumon Taungdan") are a series of mountains in the <a href="Indo-Myanmar%20border">Indo-Myanmar border</a> falling in the <a href="North%20East%20India">north-eastern Indian states</a> of <a href="Arunachal%20Pradesh">Arunachal Pradesh</a>, <a href="Nagaland">Nagaland</a> and <a href="Upper%20Burma">Upper Burma</a> region of Myanmar. They were created by the same <a href="tectonic">tectonic</a> processes that created the <a href="Himalayas">Himalayas</a> in the <a href="Mesozoic">Mesozoic</a>. In <a href="Tai-Ahom">Tai-Ahom</a> language, Pat means "to cut" and Kai means "chicken".
Geography.
The Patkai range mountains are not as rugged as the Himalayas and the peaks are much lower. Features of the range include conical peaks, steep slopes and deep valleys.
Three mountain ranges come under the Patkai. The <a href="Patkai-Bum">Patkai-Bum</a>, the <a href="Khasi%20and%20Jaintia%20Hills">Garo-Khasi-Jaintia hills</a> and the <a href="Lushai%20Hills">Lushai Hills</a>. The highest point of this range is <a href="Phawngpui">Phawngpui Tlang</a>, which is also known as 'Blue Mountain'. The Garo-Khasi range is in the Indian state of <a href="Meghalaya">Meghalaya</a>. <a href="Mawsynram">Mawsynram</a> and <a href="Cherrapunji">Cherrapunji</a>, on the <a href="windward">windward</a> side of these mountains are the world's wettest places, having the highest annual rainfall.
The climate range from <a href="temperate">temperate</a> to <a href="alpine%20climate">alpine</a> due to differences in <a href="altitude">altitude</a>.
The <a href="Pangsau%20Pass">Pangsau Pass</a> offers the most important route through the Patkai. The <a href="Ledo%20Road">Ledo Road</a> was built through Pangsau Pass as a strategic supply road over the duration of <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> to link India with the <a href="Burma%20Road">Burma Road</a> and finally onto <a href="China">China</a>.
In <a href="World%20War%202">World War 2</a>, the Patkai Range was considered a part of the <a href="The%20Hump">The Hump</a> by the <a href="Allies%20of%20World%20War%20II">Allied Forces</a>.
